audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing himself and reminiscing about a time when Pluto was reclassified as a planet. He speaks in a conversational tone, imitating pseudo-intellectuals pointing out this fact. A different male voice, speaking sternly, insists Pluto is not a planet, telling someone to "shut up." Immediately following this exchange, there is an abrupt silence.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker reminiscing about the redesign of toys, posters, and textbooks due to Pluto's reclassification. He humorously notes that this happened while a spaceship was on its way to Pluto. He then states that he is there to explain why the International Astronomical Union's decision is contentious among people with an emotional attachment to Pluto, and within the scientific community as well. A brief humorous male voice states that Pluto was a planet until a committee disagreed, and then he disagrees back. This is followed by a male speaker introducing himself and his show. The audio then transitions to a retro electronic instrumental piece, reminiscent of a video game soundtrack, that continues throughout the clip.

A single male speaker asserts that "Pluto doesn't actually care what we call it," and discusses the complexity of classifying objects in the universe, such as species, and mentions arguments around definitions. He notes that science aims to reduce things into "nice classifications," but asks if this is possible with scientific utility, speaking in a neutral, informative tone throughout.

A man begins speaking in a matter-of-fact tone, describing a hypothetical scenario of a scientist searching for phosphine. He suggests that searching for "planets as defined by the IAU" would exclude "interesting moons" and other "really interesting places." He argues that the definition of "dwarf planet" doesn't aid scientific inquiry. He continues, noting that a Google Scholar search for "dwarf planets" mainly yields papers about "M dwarf stars," indicating that scientists don't commonly use "dwarf planet" for study categorization. Simultaneously with the speech, a brief, rhythmic musical interlude of a simple, quirky tune plays, with a synthesizer and some electronic elements giving it a playful, slightly futuristic mood.

The clip begins with speech. A male speaker expresses his opinion that the vote that demoted Pluto was "weird", then describes the resolution and requirements for being a planet. He remarks the vote was far from a scientific consensus and was left to those with the time to consider the motions. The speech fades to instrumental music, sounding electronic and futuristic in tone.

A single male speaker discusses the definition of a planet, observing that it typically includes orbiting the sun, which excludes exoplanets. He also mentions that the definition doesn't address brown dwarf stars and would exclude rogue planets. His tone is analytical and critical. He presents the hypothetical situation of Earth being kicked out of the solar system, noting that it would then not be classified as a planet anymore, even though it is one. He concludes that including this in the definition is "a weird thing".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the concept of considering a planet's orbit. He mentions that Pluto was "demoted" because it has a "barycenter" between it and Sharon. He then poses a hypothetical scenario where planets as large as Jupiter are spinning around each other, stating that, under a new definition, neither would be considered planets. His tone is conversational and informative throughout.

The audio begins with a male speaker using an analogy to describe a concept. He describes a hypothetical situation about "a caveman sitting down with your friend and a bear attacked you." The speaker's tone is conversational and storytelling. After the speech, there's a brief musical interlude featuring a somber tone and strings.

The clip opens with a clear, somewhat conversational male voice discussing "the next nail in the coffin" regarding a scientific definition and referencing Pluto. The speaker's tone is informative. He mentions Google Scholar, papers classifying Pluto as a dwarf planet, and usage in papers. This spoken segment transitions into dramatic, almost eerie string music, which sounds like it might be part of a soundtrack. After a pause, the male voice returns. He asserts, "Planetary dwarfism actually has nothing to do with size," speaking with a tone of revelation. He talks about the reason planets like Ceres or Pluto are reclassified, dismissing the notion of a size-related number. The audio concludes with the speaker conveying a sense that this reclassification was specifically aimed at Pluto.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing disagreement. He continues, adopting a conversational tone, outlining how he won't complain without suggesting an alternative and discussing evolving definitions of planets, favoring a geophysical planetary definition. This leads into a second male speaker, also speaking conversationally, using an analogy comparing space objects to dogs to illustrate a point about classification. The audio concludes with this speaker emphasizing the need to classify objects by their own attributes, not by arbitrary limits.

The clip starts with a male speaker who believes "the IAU made a tragic mistake," and requests Ron's rebuttal. The speaker sounds serious, and is followed by applause. Another male then shouts excitedly.  This speaker says, "If it can be a planet, it can be a planet again," repeating the word "planet" several times in an excited, enthusiastic tone. The clip ends with a male speaker stating "I hope you enjoyed this moment."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker in a confident, conversational tone addressing a hypothetical situation. He suggests responding to someone who claims "Pluto is not a planet" by countering that "it is a planet" and "it will be a planet again." The speaker emphasizes that "this is far from over."

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing the topic of planet Pluto and its features, speaking in an informative tone. He describes it as an "active landscape" with features similar to Earth. A brief, mellow musical interlude follows, creating a calm mood. The male speaker returns, expressing hope for the listener's "astronomy journey".

The audio clip starts with a male speaker introducing himself, mentioning "Starstuff" and a nihilistic sentiment about meaninglessness and death, spoken in a somewhat detached tone. This leads into a piece of electronic music. The music is synthesizer-heavy, creating an unsettling and atmospheric mood.
